# Introduction to Variables

::: {.callout-note}
A **variable** is a name given to a storage area that programs can manipulate. It's like a labeled box where you can store data!
:::

In C++, before you can use a variable, you must **declare** it. This tells the compiler:
1.  The variable's **data type** (what kind of data it will hold).
2.  The variable's **name** (how you'll refer to it).

---

# Basic Data Types

C++ has several fundamental data types to handle different kinds of information.

| Type    | Description                                   | Example             |
| :------ | :-------------------------------------------- | :------------------ |
| `int`   | Stores whole numbers (integers)               | `10`, `-500`, `0`   |
| `double`| Stores floating-point numbers (decimals)      | `3.14`, `-0.001`    |
| `char`  | Stores single characters                      | `'A'`, `'z'`, `'5'` |
| `bool`  | Stores boolean values (true/false)            | `true`, `false`     |
| `string`| Stores sequences of characters (text)         | `"Hello"`, `"C++"`  |

---

# Declaring and Initializing Variables

You declare a variable by specifying its type and name. You can also give it an initial value (initialization).

## Declaration
```cpp
int age;           // Declares an integer variable named 'age'
double price;      // Declares a double variable named 'price'
char initial;      // Declares a character variable named 'initial'
bool isActive;     // Declares a boolean variable named 'isActive'
// string requires #include <string>
// std::string name; // Declares a string variable named 'name'
```

## Example
```{c++}
#include <iostream>
int main() {
    std::cout << "Hello!" << std::endl;
    return 0;
}
```

## Example 2
```{cpp}
// First, declare some variables
int score;
double temperature;
char level;

// Now, assign values to them
score = 95;
temperature = 25.5;
level = 'B';

std::cout << "Score: " << score << std::endl;
std::cout << "Temperature: " << temperature << std::endl;
std::cout << "Level: " << level << std::endl;

score = 100; // Change the value of score
std::cout << "New Score: " << score << std::endl;
```
